subsubsection.title: Volumes by Cross-Sections

example.statement: An isosceles triangle has a base of 10 inches and height of 5 inches. From geometry, we know that its area is 25 in^2; use integrals to find its area by slicing vertically, then by slicing horizontally.

solution.p: When slicing vertically, we get the integral \ds \int_{-5}^0 x+5\, dx + \int_0^5 -x + 5\, dx which gives an area of 25.
When slicing horizontally, we get the integral \ds \int_0^5 10-2y\, dy, which also gives an area of 25.
Multiply the base triangle area by the length of the prism, so that the volume is 25L

example.statement: Show that the volume of a right cylinder of radius r and height h has volume V = \pi r^2h

solution.p:
Let y be the vertical axis. The cross-sectional area is the area of a circle, A(y) = \pi r^2. Then, the volume of the solid is
\ds \int_0^h \pi r^2\, dy \amp = \pi r^2 y\bigg\rvert_0^h \amp = \pi r^2h

subsubsection.p: For generic volumes, we can consider cross sections of a solid, and slabs of constant width.

definition.title: Volume
definition.p:
Let S be a solid that lies between x =a and x = b. If the cross-sectional area of S in the plane P_x, through x and perpendicular to the x-axis is A(x), where A is a continuous function, then the volume of S is given by
V = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^n A(x_i^*)\,\Delta x = \int_a^b A(x)\,dx

example.statement: Show that the volume of a sphere of radius r is V = \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3

solution.p:
Since vertical cross sections are circles of raidus r, we have the relationship x^2 + y^2 = r^2, so that y = \sqrt{r^2-x^2}. This means that the cross-sectional area is given by \pi y^2 = \pi (r^2-x^2). Thus, the volume is given by
\ds \int_{-r}^r \pi (r^2-x^2)\, dx \amp = \pi r^2 x - \dfrac{1}{3}\pi x^3\bigg\rvert_{-r}^r \amp = \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3

example.statement: Draw an explicit connection between how we found area under a curve in Section 4.1 and Section 4.2, and how we've defined area here.
Use cross-sectional areas to prove that the volume of a square-based pyramid is \dfrac{1}{3}L^2h, where L is the side length of the square base, and h is the pyramid's height.

solution.p: Consider the cross-section with the tip of the pyramid at the origin, and the base at x= h. We have a line going through the origin and the point \lrpar{h,\dfrac{L}{2}}. This means the equation of the line is given by y = \dfrac{L}{2h}x.

Now, cross-sectional areas are squares; this means the height of each square is given by 2\cdot \dfrac{L}{2h}x = \dfrac{L}{h}x. So, the cross-sectional area is \dfrac{L^2}{h^2}x^2. This means the volume is given by \ds \int_0^h \dfrac{L^2}{h^2}x^2\, dx = \dfrac{1}{3}L^2h

assemblage.title: Disk Method
assemblage.p:
If f is a positive, continuous function on some interval [a,b], then the volume of the solid created by rotating f(x) about the x-axis is given by
\int_a^b \pi [r(x)]^2\, dx
where r(x) is the radius function.

assemblage.title: Washer Method
assemblage.p:
If f and g are two continuous functions on [a,b] such that f(x) \geq g(x) on [a,b], then the volume of the solid created by rotating the region between f and g is given by
\int_a^b \pi[(R(x))^2-(r(x))^2]\, dx
where R(x) is the outer radius, and r(x) is the inner radius.
